name: Arelith Dwarven Elite Guard - Rogue 4 / Fighter 10 / Weapon Master 16

posts.author: magaiti

Here is my build. I have not played much on Arelith, so any advice is appreciated.
Aiming to make a durable melee fighter with good AC/AB/crits and UMD.

Playable 1-30 PvE

For reference, relevant Arelith rules: DevCrit is disabled; first 3 levels of a class must be taken in a row, before switching to another class.

Build considerations:
 - Rogue for tumble and UMD, WM for damage/crit/AB.
 - Rogue at first level for more skillpoints and class intimidate (22 extra skillpoints)
 - trying to get best AB as well as EDR III

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
I don't play Arelith either so probably a better-informed source would be a player who has played there a lot to know what can best be exploited.  BTW, if this is not a finished, tested build, you should post it first in Unfinalized or folks will assume it is one with all the bugs worked out.  Actually, it seems pretty close to that now.  You've accounted for most all of what you need.

Your AB is about as high as it can go if you want to qualify for EDR.  And pretty good for Arelith I think.

Some things to consider:

With EDR, high CON & Expertise going for you, I believe this build mimics a fighter wall so would swap out Imp Exp for IKD (personal bias and since you've already got the INT prereq).  The thing I've found using Imp Exp with non-caster is that if enemies flank you and you feel a need for the extra 5 AC over standard Exp, you'll be attacking at +26/+21/+16/+11 non-hasted and probably be missing at least half of the time, especially in PvP who will likely have their own high AC to begin with.  I say stay as offensive as possible, put the elevated AB to work, force the opposition to try to avoid all the crits (and there SHOULD be a lot to contend with) and rely on your DR & HP soak to keep you alive while making a lot of successful attacks and crit opps. 

Even if you take a rogue level dump @30, you will suffer scroll casting failure with high-level scrolls.  ATM, w/o CHA-boosting gear, you will be hitting UMD of 28 to cast only level 3 spells w/o failure.  You'll need a modified UMD of at least 34 (or is it 33?  I forget)  to get that high assuming Arelith uses the default scroll casting check.  You'd know that better than me of course.  BTW, you should list UMD in your skill list.  I'm guessing you allocated 30 ranks, modified to 28 via CHA.

Though there is no restriction to alignment on the build I would recommend "Any neutral" as protection vs. smiters.

Your low Will save (15 vs. spells) may prove problematic vs. necromatic arcanists and clerics using negative energy.  Typically, that damage type is seldom resistable swo could become a factor especially with Fear spams.  The only thing I can thing of offhand is to test the build out a bit, decide if that AS +2 AC is making a huge difference.  If not a big issue and you are getting taunted regularly, you shift all those "handy" skills points (DT & OL specifically) and a few from heal to max Conc @31 and then swap out Armor Skin for ESkF: Conc.  With all your CON, you will win all the taunt checks guaranteed.  But that is more of a PvP design vs. specific kinds of opponents.

I'm curious what weapon you are considering.  I'm guessing either rapier or scimi, perhaps longsword.

I like the build overall and I think you gave it a lot of thought.  All that's needed now is some testing and it should be good to go.

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
While you are reevaluating, I suggest you declare up front (edit your original post) what your build is intended to address: killing monsters, dueling, or a gimped version intended to interact with the specific environment most effectively, like Arelith.  It matters.  Most PvM & PvE builds will be too weak in some key areas to vie with other players' power builds so declare your expectations and refine accordingly, please.  No build can excel in all areas of gameplay.
But battleaxe/warhammer are slightly better against high AC, also more dwarf-flavored.
Well, I understand the roleplay bias issue, but exactly how can those weapons become more effective against higher AC. You mean the x3 crit multiplier?  But a scimi/rapier will crit 3x as often.  In other words, to gain about 40% more damage per crit (includes the base damage), you are sacrificing around 65% more crit opportunities.  Or is there some extra advantage for those weapon types on Arelith?

posts.author: Dante2377
posts.content:
Hip - I think he means that against higher AC opponents, the extra threat range beyond 17-20 (or 16-20 keen) won't hit anyway (e.g. a 15 or lower will miss, particularly non first attacks, against those opponents) so might as well have the bigger multiplier.  Max made a similar argument in one of his WM builds back in the day (think it was the paladin one, but not sure). 

But it will actually depend on a lot of different factors including specific AB vs AC range of "tough" opponents, do the opponents use DR or % immunity, what sort of damage bonuses are available [eg adding 12 x 2d8 damage bonuses vs a more standard environment with a few d6/d8s].  If you know or can estimate the above, you can create a spreadsheet to calculate ave damage per round vs that AC range.

Now you are confusing me. Aren't PvE and PvM exactly the same concepts?
The build is not intended for competitive PvP. When I made it, I had party/solo doungeneering in mind, so PvE.

 
According to my calculations, 16-20x4 profile (axe, WM) does 20% less damage per round than 10-20x3 (scimitar, WM) when enemy has negligible AC.
This difference becomes 13% when enemy AC is 10 better than your AB, still in favor of scimitar.
Parity happens around AC ~ AB+13, and after that axe is 5-10% better that scimitar, evening out again when you begin to hit only on rolls of 20.
Basically, this happens when wide crit of scimitar becomes useless because you can't crit when you can't hit.
Powergaming wise, scimitar is better unless you are building specifically to fight against monsters/players with such high AC.
On the other hand, scimitar is often frowned upon on RP servers, as its an easy powergaming choice.

Apologies.  I'll try to clarify.

A PvM design is strictly combat vs. monsters and within the context of that build, ignoring PvP considerations completely.

A PvP design is designed to dominate player build in duels or team competition, and ideally, exploits the weakness(es) of specific class combos.

A PvE design is used for combat (could be PvM and/or PvP), traps, locks, bashing, merchandising, dealing with low-mid-high magic level... essentially anything that is intrinsic to a particular server or category of server. For PvE builds, it's preferable to outline the significant nuances of the server that you intend to take advantage of so others considering the build can easily tweak it for their own situation. Just as one example where skill allocation is considered... a few servers I've played supplied heal kits as the basic HP restoration device, few (if any) potions and significant rest limitations. So, on those servers it would be wise to allocate as many spare (non-power) skill ranks in Heal as you can afford. Yet... on other servers, the Heal skill is all but worthless.
 According to my calculations, 16-20x4 profile (axe, WM) does 20% less damage per round than 10-20x3 (scimitar, WM) when enemy has negligible AC.

posts.author: magaiti
posts.content:
Rapier base damage is piercing, so it cannot be enchanted with default keen spell, in this regard it is strictly worse than scimitar.
Unless used in a specific environment, where piercing is better than slashing.
RP wise, rapier is designed for dexterous combatants, and a hulking armored juggernaut with a thin blade just looks silly.

Kukri is an exotic weapon, and thus balanced.

As for "keen clubs", I know one server where clerics have "weapon of impact" spell, which works exactly like keen, but only on blunt weapons (they still show "keen temporary" property, engine limitation i assume).
So for blunt weapons, it can be rationalized that they just become enchanted in a way that allows the wielder to swing more efficiently,  hitting their target with more kinetic force, thus increasing chance of shattering armor/bones.
